header.title: LIBER 20: Reincarnation and Esoteric Interpretations of The Lord's Prayer
authors: I. C. E. S. (International College of Esoteric Studies)

central_thesis: LIBER 20 aims to elucidate fundamental esoteric concepts such as Reincarnation and Karma within a framework that harmonizes with traditional religious doctrines (Christianity, Martinism, Gnosticism, Eastern philosophies) and to provide a deep, operative understanding of the Lord's Prayer as a condensed ancient science and a powerful system of spiritual affirmations and practices for personal and collective mystical enlightenment and the manifestation of divine will on Earth.

structure_content.chapter_title: CONTINUATION FROM LIBER 19 OF THE LECTURE GIVEN BY SISTER ASUNTA
structure_content.summary: This section explores the concept of 'dissolute will' as the source of human error and suffering, advocating for internal self-mastery and alignment with one's inherent law to achieve peace. It defines 'good' as the realization of one's own law and 'evil' as that which opposes it, emphasizing the importance of looking within for truth.

This lecture introduces reincarnation as a core occult principle, essential for understanding the Laws of Compensation and Karma. It differentiates reincarnation from transmigration (devolution) and supports its truth with philosophical arguments, the brevity of human life, and citations from early Christian Fathers and various esoteric traditions, categorizing societal views on the subject.

This part provides a meditation exercise on biblical verses for self-discovery and evolutionary understanding. It discusses 'transmigration' within the Order of St. Martin, aligning it with universal religious tenets. It delves into spirit dissociation as a path to Nirvana, supported by biblical examples and references to Rosicrucian, Mussulman, and Buddhist traditions.

This lecture offers a detailed Qabalistic and Gnostic analysis of the Lord's Prayer. It interprets the prayer's petitions as stages of spiritual work involving the mind, heart, and will, mapping them to the Sephiroth of the Tree of Life and the Four Worlds. It provides practical applications for manifesting divine will through understanding the prayer's esoteric correspondences and elemental purification.

structure_content.chapter_title: GNOSTIC — SUPERNUMERARY LECTURE #20 (The Lord's Prayer as Affirmation)
structure_content.summary: This section presents an alternative, operative interpretation of the Lord's Prayer as a series of positive statements and affirmations, rather than supplications. It focuses on achieving spiritual unity, manifesting inner divine potential, and dissolving conflicts through self-awareness and conditional forgiveness, redefining prayer as a 'disposition' of oneness and knowing.

key_concepts.definition: The cyclical process of the soul inhabiting successive bodies, essential for spiritual evolution and the working out of Karma, explicitly differentiated from retrogression into lower animal forms ('transmigration').

The principle that actions or 'debts' incur consequences that must be balanced, often through subsequent reincarnations; summarized by 'as a man sows, so shall he reap,' necessitating rebirth until all debts are paid.

Man's inherent tendency to act against his own divine nature or 'law of being,' leading to suffering and error, which requires conscious effort and self-mastery to overcome and achieve peace with nature.

The ability of the spirit to separate from the physical body, a concept found in ancient texts and considered an 'essential qualification' for spiritual control and the attainment of higher states like Samadi.

The ultimate spiritual goal; in a Martinist context, to be reabsorbed in אָדֹמָ (primordial man); in a Buddhist context, the highest state of felicity where the immortal spirit loses bodily states to become one with Deity while remaining individually and eternally happy.

Viewed not as a mere supplication but as a condensed ancient science, a Qabalistic map of divine principles, and a sequence of potent affirmations for spiritual transformation and theurgic manifestation, addressing the mind, heart, and will.

A central esoteric system used to understand the divine structure (Sephiroth) and map the Lord's Prayer's petitions to specific divine attributes and energies (Kether, Chokmah, Binah, Chesed, Geburah, Tiphereth, Netzach, Hod, Yesod, Malkuth), as well as the Four Worlds (Atziluth, Briah, Ietzirah, Assiah).

The practical application of divine will on Earth by aligning human mind, heart, and will with celestial forces, exemplified by living 'Thy will be done on earth as it is in heaven' through conscious effort and specific practices to manifest spiritual realities.

A practical method involving invoking the presiding Angels of the four elements (Earth, Water, Air, Fire) to cleanse impurities from the physical body, heart, intellect, and to sanctify the soul and spirit.

A technique where the Lord's Prayer is recited not as asking but as positive statements of unity with God, declarations of inherent divine potential, and acceptance of divine supply and forgiveness, transforming the practitioner's inner state and outer reality.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in LIBER 20 centers on integrating esoteric knowledge (Reincarnation, Karma, Qabalah) with active spiritual practices, particularly focusing on the Lord's Prayer as a multi-layered tool. It moves from intellectual understanding to the cultivation of specific inner states (mind, heart, will) and the manifestation of divine principles in daily life. This is achieved through meditation, self-observation, active forgiveness, and affirmations, all aimed at aligning the individual's microcosm with the macrocosm and fulfilling their evolutionary purpose.
tools: The Lord's Prayer (interpreted as a Qabalistic map and a sequence of affirmations).
Knowledge of the Tree of Life / Sephiroth and their correspondences to divine attributes and human faculties.
Awareness of the Four Elements and their presiding Angels for purification practices.
Scriptural texts (Bible, Koran, Vedas, Shastras, Zendavesta) for comparative study and deeper insight into universal esoteric truths.
Self-reflection, introspection, and self-observation to develop 'super-conscious memory' and identify and transform the 'dissolute will'.
rituals: Meditation on Matthew 17:12-13 and Job 14:14 for self-discovery and understanding of personal evolution.
Purification practice involving invoking the presiding Angels of the four elements (Earth, Water, Air, Fire) to cleanse impurities from the physical body, heart, intellect, soul, and spirit.
Contemplation of sunrise to absorb luminous qualities and harmonize with divine forces, embodying 'like the sun'.

Daily recitation of the Lord's Prayer as a Qabalistic meditation and powerful affirmations, linking its phrases to specific Sephiroth and cultivating corresponding mental, emotional, and volitional states (e.g., light for mind, love for heart, divine will for action).

relevant_quotes.text: The subject of reincarnation confronts the student of occult and spiritual Mysteries at the very beginning of his progress on the Path and without an understanding of it (theoretically at least), he cannot otherwise fully comprehend the Laws of Compensation and Karma, upon which the evolution of humanity is both ethically and organically based.

Reincarnation or Rebirth is NOT transmigration, or the descent of the soul into lower animals, for that would imply retrogression or devolution. As we have already seen, the Law is: EVOLUTION ... progress, the onward, forward movement of all.

Saint Gregory of Nyssa, who lived A.D. 257-333, has the following to say: “It is absolutely necessary that the soul should be healed and purified, and if this does not take place during its life on earth it must be accomplished in future lives.”

The Martinist may be of any cult, he understands that every creed or religion inculcates God, all terminate at the same point; he is his great hope is that he will one day attain Nirvana — be reabsorbed in אָדֹמָ

Prayer is not something we do to God, but something we do to ourselves. It is not a position, but a disposition. on. It is not flattery, but a sense of oneness. It is not asking, but knowing. It is not words, but feeling. It is not will, but willingness.
“Hallowed be Thy name” means: “Wholeness and perfection is the nature of God.”

The first three requests of the Lord's Prayer, then, correspond to the three principles in man: the mind, which must be full of light in order to illumine and make all things holy; the feelings or heart, the central powerhouse which must become God's Kingdom, the Kingdom of peace and of love for all creatures; and finally the will which corresponds to the physical dimension in which, by our acts, we have to express and reflect all that is in Heaven.

The idea of karma is based on this truth: that we have to come back to this earth in order to pay for transgressions committed in previous incarnations Someone who has paid off all his debts need not reincarnate.
I believe the original prayer would probably have said: “Give us the strength to resist temptation.”

critical_analysis.relevance: This Liber is highly relevant for students of Western Esotericism, particularly those interested in Martinism, Gnosticism, and Hermetic Qabalah, as it provides a synthesis of these traditions to interpret core spiritual concepts (reincarnation, karma) and a foundational prayer (the Lord's Prayer). It bridges the gap between traditional Christian dogma and esoteric understanding, offering a practical framework for spiritual evolution and self-mastery. Its exploration of universal principles across diverse religious traditions demonstrates an inclusive, syncretic approach typical of broader occult philosophy.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The material is explicitly intended for 'students of occult and spiritual Mysteries,' 'receiving members' of the International College of Esoteric Studies (I.C.E.S.), and 'Initiates.' It presumes a foundational understanding of esoteric concepts and a willingness to engage in deep study, meditation, and self-reflection. The 'Craftsman' grade indicates it's for those already initiated into a specific path, seeking deeper, operative knowledge and practical application.
